I have been playing Out of the Park Baseball since 2004, but have always wished that there was a better mobile interface for the reports.

After toying around with mobile browser detection, I ultimately decided on creating a dedicated app. In my opinion it provides a better user interface, as well as gives a bit of flexibility for offline use. It also provided me with a bit of experience learning some Android programming.

string-array.name: faq_questions
string-array.item: So how does this thing work?
How do I find out the CSV and HTML paths?
Why can\'t I put spaces in the universe name?
Some of the views come up blank when I\'m pretty sure they shouldn\'t, what\'s happening?
Why are some things missing from the box scores?
Why isn\'t there an iPhone version of this?

string-array.name: faq_answers
string-array.item: Simply provide a name for your universe (really, it could be anything distinctive) and the paths to the universe\'s CSV and HTML files. When the universe is intiailized, the necessary CSV files are downloaded and parsed into an internal database. That database is what all of the views are populated from.

Generally speaking, the CSV is located in a "csv" folder directly off of the league's root URL (http://www.yourleague.com/csv/).

The URL path is usually the main reports directory for your league. So, for example, if the main index file for your league is http://www.yourleague.com/reports/news/html/index.html, then the root path this app needs is http://www.yourleague.com/reports/.

That being said, it's best to check with the commissioner of your league to get the appropraite paths.

The HTML path is optional, but recommended for the best experience.

Universe names need to be restricted to alphanumeric strings without spaces because the tables are created based on the CSV files. I prepend the universe name to the tables (universe_players, and so forth) to essentially serve as a key to keep the universes separated.

Blank views are usually the result of queries that have returned no data because the tables never got populated correctly because of errors downloading the CSV files. The app should notify you if a download error has occurred, but simply refreshing the universe will take care of it the vast majority of the time.

If possible, the box score from your league's web server is used as the source for the box score data. However, if the box score cannot be found for any reason, I generate a box score from the CSV files as a fallback. Unfortunately, there are limitations due to what is stored in the CSV.

For example, pinch hitters and pinch runners are not distinguished, so I have to guess based on plate appearances - if a pinch-runner stays in the game and gets a plate appearance later on, I have not figured out a way of determining that.

Similarly, defensive subs that don't get a plate appearance are not referenced, and there is no per-game fielding information stored in the CSV.

Relief pitchers may appear out of order, as the actual order of appearance is not stored. I can figure out what innings they appeared in which is right a lot of the time, but if multiple pitchers are used in an inning I haven't figured out how to determine proper order.

Minor leauge box scores are even worse, as the fields that determine batting order and pitching innigs are not populated for minor league games so the batters and any relievers are listed in order of their OOTP player ID.
I don\'t have a Mac or an iPhone, that\'s why. ;)
